Posts.Content: hi peterawake yes, the lymph node one was 4mm, almost half the size of the node (9mm) so I thought quite big.... and never detected beforehand which was surprising since it was checked twice by ultrasound. The tumour removed was 18mm, initially diagnosed as 14mm but due to no clear margins it was further excised. My surgeon mentioned he managed to find only one other sentinel node and that one was clear. I had surgery in February last year and still have a green tinge in the bottom half of my breast, so I guess that indeed I do have fewer nodes to remove the invasive dye... I am not sure if that is good or bad as any cancer cells have to go somewhere, but I rather not think about that. I asked about chemo at the time but they said there was no real benefit to me, although as my treatment developed they also changed their mind about booster radiation sessions. Initially I was to get 4, but these were cancelled as again, they felt I would not benefit based on where the original tumour was (against my skin) and so in effect it could not further spread, so to speak. I had 8/8 Estroegen and 6/6 Progestron, so really at the tip of the scale so I am guessing that the letrozole + radiation will do the trick. What scares me is what will happen 10 years down the line as this type of cancer seems to lie dormant for a long time...\ GC
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hi sarahmaria I had a similar problem. It is very hard to tell. I was fine with Accord for a while, and then all of a sudden could not tolerate it. I also had Reddys and Teva. It just occurred to me that bisphosphonates cause the same intolerance issues... I had it bad after the 2nd infusion... I have stopped taken letrozole for 3 weeks, and will then switch ... what to not sure yet. Hope it will work out for you. GC
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hello Cuppatime and everyone else interested in the cost of letrozole there is a website listing the costs of some of the brands https://bnf.nice.org.uk/medicinal-forms/letrozole.html strangely, CIPLA is not on that list and that was the one bothering me most. It is made by an Indian company. I asked my GP if I could get letrzole Femara as I had read it was causing fewer side effects. However this was denied as apparently this would increase my medication cost by £900 per year. When I spoke to the hospital they said they could insist though as of course they would rather have me continue then run the risk of recurrence, which would be a lot more costly... GC
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hi sarahmaria I had a similar problem. It is very hard to tell. I was fine with Accord for a while, and then all of a sudden could not tolerate it. I also had Reddys and Teva. It just occurred to me that bisphosphonates cause the same intolerance issues... I had it bad after the 2nd infusion... I have stopped taken letrozole for 3 weeks, and will then switch ... what to not sure yet. Hope it will work out for you. GC
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hi Sharon yes I totally agree about things developing and hopeful that one day a blood test will be able to detect any recurrence, really do believe in that. with regards to boosters I was told that in the case of high grade the original bed where the invasive cancer was located is targeted. for me the high grade was in the DCIS and as this was completely removed they were confident there was no need for the booster, more so as the invasive cancer was against the skin and that had 1mm margin on one side, rest all clear margins. So I am crossing my fingers now. GC
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hi lovely ladies How many of you have tried different brands pf letrozole? I decided that Accord was best for me but then my chemist annoyingly gave me Cipla. I have had horrendous side effects these past 5 days, it is quite debilitating... anyone else had that experience? I am analyzing the ingredients of each; it seems the film coating is quite different... I am not sure if I just had a bad time in general and felt awful, or indeed it was CIPLA to blame... I also asked Femara as I heard that was best, but my GP would not prescribe it saying it costs an extra £900 a year.... I think it is terrible we have no choice in these matters and must plea all the time to get something which ultimately will affect me for the next 10 years... Anyway, just wondered if anyone else felt the same. GC
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hi moomy and Leolady56 yes I am aware the discussions have popped up so many times...  Just wanted to find out if there had been any progress. Amazing there is so much research but nothing on SE.... I have been on letrozole for 10 months now, not that long of course, but with plenty of ups and downs for SE I had to make a fuss at my chemist about 6 months ago and eventually my GP agreed to specify 'accord' and SE seem reasonable now but still having bad fatigue. The last time however, after the femara 'rejection', my GP just sent a prescription and I ended up getting Cipla.I thought I would give it a go but it is hell I am not a chemist but thought I would check on the ingredients,  It is baffling that such minute differences can have such massive effects.  My oncologist said for me I would be  on it for 10 years, I was told I could stop a few months and see how things settle down. Apparently a break is fine. But stopping also freaks me out... Thanks for all your supporting comments, it means a lot to me. GC
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hi peterawake yes, the lymph node one was 4mm, almost half the size of the node (9mm) so I thought quite big.... and never detected beforehand which was surprising since it was checked twice by ultrasound. The tumour removed was 18mm, initially diagnosed as 14mm but due to no clear margins it was further excised. My surgeon mentioned he managed to find only one other sentinel node and that one was clear. I had surgery in February last year and still have a green tinge in the bottom half of my breast, so I guess that indeed I do have fewer nodes to remove the invasive dye... I am not sure if that is good or bad as any cancer cells have to go somewhere, but I rather not think about that. I asked about chemo at the time but they said there was no real benefit to me, although as my treatment developed they also changed their mind about booster radiation sessions. Initially I was to get 4, but these were cancelled as again, they felt I would not benefit based on where the original tumour was (against my skin) and so in effect it could not further spread, so to speak. Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hi Sharon yes I totally agree about things developing and hopeful that one day a blood test will be able to detect any recurrence, really do believe in that. with regards to boosters I was told that in the case of high grade the original bed where the invasive cancer was located is targeted. for me the high grade was in the DCIS and as this was completely removed they were confident there was no need for the booster, more so as the invasive cancer was against the skin and that had 1mm margin on one side, rest all clear margins. So I am crossing my fingers now. GC
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hi GRANNY59 I have decided on my own experiment: I stopped taking Cipla for just 24 hours, and I immediately felt better. I have now taken it again and see what tomorrow brings. I just wanted to see if indeed it was Cipla and nothing else. If it is Cipla then I will re-order Accord only. I do hope it is available, a bit worrying you think it might not be... My BCN mentioned to me that the hospital can insist on specific prescriptions at my GP, including femara as the hospital believe it is better for me to be reassured and take it for 10 years compared to me stopping and then running the risk of recurrence. In the end it is all down to cost... I think I have taken teva just once in the 10 months but at the time I had 3 different brands in a row, no wonder it caused havoc in my system... Yes, getting Macmillan involved would be great. It is so hard to endure this for such a very long time. We go through surgery, radiotherapy (I did not have chemo) and after a few months, everything is 'back to normal'. But I think with letrozole nothing is quite normal. It is such a challenging drug with so many SE and so many women having different reactions.... Sending you a big hug. GC
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hello Cuppatime and everyone else interested in the cost of letrozole there is a website listing the costs of some of the brands https://bnf.nice.org.uk/medicinal-forms/letrozole.html strangely, CIPLA is not on that list and that was the one bothering me most. It is made by an Indian company. I asked my GP if I could get letrzole Femara as I had read it was causing fewer side effects. However this was denied as apparently this would increase my medication cost by £900 per year. When I spoke to the hospital they said they could insist though as of course they would rather have me continue then run the risk of recurrence, which would be a lot more costly... GC
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hello all I had my final zap # 15 today and last night I could not sleep with worry... it was all very weird and surreal walking into the hospital and then 10 minutes later it was all over. For me I officially and unexpected started this journey on the 24th of Jan, so less than 3 months ago. I sometimes find it hard to believe. Once the RT is over, it is considered finished but in a sense it is just starting in a different way.  I wish you all ladies the best of luck. I will be joining the other group 'Life after cancer' but will now and again dip into this one to see how you are all doing. cheers GC
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: hi Happygolucky280  we might see each other then as my appointment is at 8.50! I am finishing my RT on the 17th of April, so some overlap. I have sessions too. yes, traffic will be busy... but you will find lots of parking spaces and just bring your letter. And fortunately it is free to park too. take care and good luck with your treatment in case we miss each other. GC
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: I initially had 4 booster sessions planned which were then to my surprise (and worry) cancelled. I was told that my high grade DCIS, which was 2mm in size, was initially identified as being located outside the invasive cancer tumor, an analysis based on the lumpectomy biopsy report. But after further review, the oncology team then considered the DCIS within the same invasive tumor area, a total of 18mm. The margin was close for the side of the DCIS, but because the location was next to my skin, they were satisfied that the cancer cells could not spread further in that particular location and therefore the tumor bed did not need a boost. Another main reason for having a booster is age. If you are less than 50 you will usually get a booster in order to reduce the risk of recurrence later on (I am 56). I had a grade 2, stage I cancer, ER+ and PR+ but HER2-. I had 1/2 positive node and now having extensive RT... I do think it is all very confusing ... it took me quite a few attempts at getting the info clarified. GC
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: hi Twinkle51 indeed, sad when not everyone gets the same.  I mentioned it on a previous post somewhere but copy it again here. When I arrived at the Western General in Edinburgh for my radiotherapy I got a bag with the following + instructions: (1) twice a day Zerobase emollient cream (=Diprobase moisturising cream, it comes in 500 gms dispensing tub) (2) once day in the evening a thin application of Betnovate cream (=Betamethasone steroid cream 0.1%) as a preventive measure in case any skin goes infected (100 gms tube) I am today on session 13 (lucky 13 :) ) and so far so good. My skin hardly shows any sign, just a wee glow around my neck which the RT nurse says is very common. I was quite anxious getting rashes and blisters as my skin always burns in the sun and goes very patchy but now at least it seems fine.... I would certainly recommend this cream and might be easier to get it on prescription? GC
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hello everyone anyone in Scotland getting RT at the moment?  Today I am halfway, session 8 out of 15.  So far I have not had any side effects other than feeling tired. I did notice a very very slight reddish effect, but ever so slight and I have upped the cream we receive here, when we start the RT, to 3 times a day. I am aware moisturising advice in Scotland is different.... I am on Letrozole (about 6 weeks so far) and again had no side effects at all. I feel such a fraud... and I am worried that everything is gonna hit me all at once, once I have finished with my treatment in 2 weeks' time. I am due to fly out then, so hope I will not fall apart. GC
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi everyone Has anyone experienced problems with a boss who has a contradictory attitude: i.e. accepting working fewer hours but still insisting on a a large, even increased workload. I am dealing with a boss who is very undermining, constantly criticising and I am at the end of my tether. I have contacted my union but it may take some time before I hear back. Just wondered if anyone has been dealing with this recently? I know that cancer is covered under the disability act and I was diagnosed exactly 1 year go. I have had successful treatment but side effects are still making me feel very tired. Now I have extra anxiety and worry, getting very depressed and I feel I am being pushed out of a job that I used to do very well.... worried sick... GC
Posts.Title: changes in the workplace and having a hard time

Posts.Content: I called but the work related advice line is only open during the week, 8.00-6pm. So will try on Monday thanks,GC
Posts.Title: changes in the workplace and having a hard time

Posts.Content: thanks! will try but as I am at work it is not so easy. But will find a quiet spot somewhere. GC
Posts.Title: changes in the workplace and having a hard time

Posts.Content: hello 232pookie it seems you and me are quite similar. my SE fee period was about 3 months on letrozile, and just a few weeks on Anstrazole...  I never really suffered from back ache before so it comes as a shock to experience it every day, especially at night. I have contacted my GP and she offered me a CT scan, but I will also check with my BC nurse, as Leolady already suggested. Hopefully there is nothing sinister going on, but better playing it safe. I had my sugery last year February and all went well, but now and again it does give me panic attacks of it coming back.... take care! GC
Posts.Title: back pain and anastrozole

Posts.Content: hello everyone I switched just over 2 months ago from letrozole to anastrozole and initially no side effects. However, for the past 2-3 weeks I experienced back ache which has increasingly gotten worse, especially at night. Anyone else had this on this drug? With letrozole I had terrible bone, muscle  and joint pain. This seems much more concentrated and I feel my spine being compressed. I am also on bisphosphonates every 6 months. thanks, GC
Posts.Title: back pain and anastrozole

Posts.Content: hi Poppy58  I got a copy of my pathology reports too and made an appointment with the local Maggie centre. They are excellent at giving you the extra details and very supportive in case anything is unclear or more worrying. all the best with your treatment GC
Posts.Title: HELP Breast cancer results interpretation

Posts.Content: hi Linda You have gone through so much already, I am just beginning. I had the operation last Wednesday and still waiting on the results of that biopsy. It is an anxious time at the moment although I feel fine, with not too much pain, a bit tired and lots of worry... I am still getting used to the idea of having the breast cancer, seems all surreal, with 3 weeks between diagnosis and surgery. It would be nice to meet up, just let me know. I live in west Edinburgh and pretty flexible at the moment. GC
Posts.Title: Edinburgh group

Posts.Content: hi I wonder if anyone knows of an Edinburgh Breast Cancer group who meets up? I don't have any family nearby and although most of my friends know about my breast cancer (I only found out myself just over 4 weeks ago) , many work and it would be good to make new friends to have a laugh, and a cry no doubt. I live in the city and work at the University. Any suggestions welcome!
Posts.Title: Edinburgh group

Posts.Content: hi Dreamthief thanks, I contacted the one based in the Western General hospital, but just wondered if there are other groups too. This is very helpful actually as I forgot about the map! thanks, GC
Posts.Title: Edinburgh group

Posts.Content: Hi 'Edinburgh group' I did some research and there is a group listed on the Macmillan map and it's called Reach for Recovery. It is based at the Western General Hospital but it seems more a support group for new patients who are attending hospital. It has been going for 30 years but at the moment they are waiting on PVG clearance and are not open. I have arranged to have coffee tomorrow with one of the volunteers to find out what plans they have. It would be good to have some sort of a social get together if anyone else is interested? I live in North West Edinburgh/Drum Brae and the local new library does Macmillan coffee mornings. The bus route 26 stops outside the library and this bus has an excellent service incl Haymarket and Princes Street. There are also plenty of parking spaces nearby. I can make an inquiry at the library if there was a chance to meet there. I could find out if a morning during the week would be feasable. I do intend to go back to work soon, I cannot afford not to, so any suggestions are welcome, including a weekend group which may well be more convenient? Say at saturday at 11.00? Or we could have floating days and plan just the dates, and depending who can make it choose different locations? There are plenty of coffee shops who would welcome us. It would be great to meet up. I have no family here and it can be pretty lonely....My husband and kids are great, but don't want to bore them and also share too many anxieties in case they worry... Thanks GC
Posts.Title: Edinburgh group

Posts.Content: hi All I hae arranged with one of the other ladies to meet tomorrow Tuesday at Drumbrae library between 11-1pm there is another macmillan coffee meeting on Thursday from 12.00-2pm, I can laso go along to that one. Just let me know. thanks, GC
Posts.Title: Edinburgh group

Posts.Content: Okay, I hope so too, thanks for letting me know.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and now numb breast

Posts.Content: I am still coming to terms with my routine breast screening on the 9th of Jan 2018.. I never felt anything and before I realised I got the cancer confirmation and a lumpectomy on Valentine's day. The surgery was standard procedure and I was a day patient taken home in the evening.... I am now recovering, only day 2... I don't feel sore at all... I took just a few pain killers yesterday  but now hardly feel anything..... BUT it feels numb... under my arm and bottom and front side of my boop.. My left arm has a constant tingling sensation, like pins and needles but not as bad....I had some nodes removed which seems standard procedure. My cancer was very small and they used a wire for assisting the surgery procedure. Has anyone had a similar experience?
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and now numb breast

Posts.Content: thanks. Yes seems very gentle this. I also joined a FB page, a closed group, but that was quite full on, with a lot of very mixed cases, some quite upsetting. I am not sure if I will keep in that group. FB does not have the capacity to direct threads, all very linear, no tags, no groups. Cancer for me was so totally unexpected, I don't feel ill. And never thought I would get it.... Sometimes I think it is just not me, but alas, I have seen the high res images, and I could see the cells myself. One day at the time and hopefully in the end I will beat it.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and now numb breast

Posts.Content: Yes I heard about the nerves being disturbed too, hope it will sort itself out. It is ever so weird. Thanks for sharing.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and now numb breast

Posts.Content: hi peterawakeI had one node with 4mm cancer which went undetected during ultrasound scan, but discovered during my lumpectomy surgery and sentinel removal. The surgeon could only find just one other node but fortunately that one was clear.I was told that chemo would not give any benefit as there are too many side effects that outweigh the risks. You can check the predict tool, and vary the different options. I thought it was quite useful but ultimately it very difficult to get a definite answer....https://predict.nhs.uk/index.htmlI had radiotherapy and then now on letrozole tablets, plus 6 monthly bisphosphonates. I am hoping for the best now.Take care GC
Posts.Title: micrometastasis

Posts.Content: hi In Scotland you have to request a report through the data protection officer at the hospital. I completed a form and received acknowledgement saying it can take up to 40 days by which time my treatment will be over. It is VERY frustrating to not get anything in writing.  GC
Posts.Title: Scan reports

Posts.Content: hi maggiemee Oh I see now, in effect your lactose intolerance is probably quite serious,   I understand. No for me it would be the fatigue, aching joints and muscle pain which I am getting quite fed up with. I checked the side effects of the 3 drugs and it all seems so similar. It's like needles in haystacks..... I have no idea and I am not sure not taking the drugs as it scares me I will loose protection maybe, although they say it stays in your system for a while..... It is all so confusing. thanks, Gina
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: Hi ladies just wondered if anyone tried switching to another 'cousin' drug of letrozole (that's what my BCN called it) and found it any better? I am wary to stop taking letrozole but the side effects have been bothering me, stiff joints, painful legs and muscles, endless fatigue.... My BCN mentioned Arimidex and Aromasin So if anyone tried switching and felt better I would like to hear your stories! When I read up I find they all cause similar side effects, so would it help to switch at all? thanks, GC
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: hello taralou, maggiemee and WhatHappened I have stopped taking the letrozole 2 days ago now, and I am all in doubt.... I guess I was looking for reassurances of those that have switched medication. My BCN mentioned it happens a lot so hoping someone will respond saying they have switched and it improved My side effects were increasing though in these last few weeks, as if my body really did not want it. I know one can argue if that is the case it must work well, but having to deal with this for maybe another 9 years and 5 months seems hard.... I work fulltime and these last few weeks have been a nightmare with fatigue and painful joints, muscles, bones, knees and fingers. I can take painkillers but it seems to me that also has a risk in the longterm. I am signed off work for the moment, the first since my surgery and I don't think I can keep a FT job like this, so willing to try out something else for the sake of improving the longterm prospects. But as I said I feel quite anxious now, perhaps I should just stick it out. GC
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: hello Purplemarriane and all you other lovely ladies thanks for all your replies. In the end I decided to go back to letrozole after stopping for just 2 days....  I was just too scared to stop taking it. Strangely my symptoms did improve. But I have now also started to take painkillers to get some relief and will probably keep taking the letrozole until I am one year in (Feb 2019) and then decide what to do... As I have my first scan since diagnosis coming up soon, I thought I wait to see what comes out of that. Anyway, that's what I am thinking just now. I am on sick leave with another few days before I am due to go back to work fulltime. I am dreading that more as the job drains me of all energy. GC
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: hi Ju 26 I have decided to continue with the letrozole. I am hoping that eventually the side effects will settle down. I don't see nay benefits of switching as all the AIs seems to have something or another... I just had a scan and got the results back and these were good, no evidence of 'recurrent disease', so I am gonna stick with it. I hope that by the time I am 12 months down the line with letrozole I can cope with it... My BCN mentioned I can stop for 3 months just before I go on holiday in March next year, in case my aches and pains are still too much for me, but will see. GC
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: hi maggiemee so did you move to the new drug. Exemestane was also mentioned to me so keen to find out... I have taken letrozole for around 8 months which did not seem very long. At first I had no side effects at all, for at least 3 months, but then gradually it started to take a cumulative effect and got worse and worse.... now my BCN says I will need to take letrozole or whatever for 10 years and I'm thinking how on earth am I going to cope. So I am keen to change but just wondered if it would work..... thanks, GC
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: hello Purplemarriane did you stop taking Anastrazole for a few weeks before you switched to Tamoxifen GC
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...
